page.title: 6.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This lesson invites students to explore polynomial division. Using the Quotient Property for exponents, students will first learn to divide monomials by monomials, as well as larger polynomials by monomials. They will use long division to divide different polynomials by binomials. Students will learn an efficient method to divide a polynomial by a binomial of the form \(x - c\) called synthetic division. Students will divide polynomial functions using the skills they have learned in the lesson. They will learn the Remainder Theorem and Factor Theorem, which they can use to check their work while dividing polynomials.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Divide by monomials by simplifying divisible terms and using the Quotient Property for exponents.
  • Use long division to divide polynomials.
  • Use synthetic division to divide polynomials by binomials of the form \(x - c\).
  • Divide polynomial functions using the methods learned in this lesson.
  • Use the Remainder Theorem to determine the remainder of a polynomial division expression.
  • Use the Factor Theorem to determine if a binomial is a factor of a polynomial.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Divide monomials.
  • Divide a polynomial by a monomial.
  • Divide polynomials using long division.
  • Divide polynomials using synthetic division.
  • Divide polynomial functions.
  • Use the Remainder and Factor Theorems.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A10(C) determine the quotient of a polynomial of degree one and polynomial of degree two when divided by a polynomial of degree one and polynomial of degree two when the degree of the divisor does not exceed the degree of the dividend;

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 6.3.1: Dividing by Monomials
  • 6.3.2: Dividing Polynomials Using Long Division
    • 6.3.2: Self Check
    • 6.3.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.3.3: Dividing Polynomials Using Synthetic Division
    • 6.3.3: Self Check
    • 6.3.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.3.4: Dividing Polynomial Functions and the Remainder Theorem
    • 6.3.4: Self Check
    • 6.3.4: Additional Resources
  • 6.3.5: Using the Factor Theorem

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 6.3.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary

  • monomial
  • binomial
  • trinomial
  • polynomial
  • polynomial function
  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their judgment.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • The Key to Reading People
  • Risky Business

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Judgment from Character Lab.

page.title: 6.3.1: Dividing by Monomials
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm-up introduces division by monomials. The first example shows a monomial divided by a monomial. The following exercises provide practice dividing binomials by monomials. Students will learn to simplify the division expressions by dividing the coefficients and using the Quotient Property for exponents on the variables.

Launch

Review the first example of monomial division as a class, \(-54a^6b^3 \div 9a^4b^2\). Ask students for answers before looking at the revealed content. Discuss each step of the division while monitoring for any student questions.

Allow students to work on exercises 1–3 individually. Before the exercises, review the following vocabulary with students to avoid confusion.

divisor: A divisor is a value by which another value is to be divided.
dividend: A dividend is a value to be divided by another value.
quotient: A quotient is the result of a division problem.
remainder: A remainder is the amount left over when performing division. It is expressed as a fraction with the remainder value in the numerator and the divisor in the denominator.

Student Activity

Look at the division expression \(-54a^6b^3 \div 9a^4b^2\).

  1. Rewrite the division expression as a fraction.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:
Fraction form: \(\frac{-54a^6b^3}{9a^4b^2}\)

  1. Since we have a monomial divided by a monomial, we can rewrite the fraction as a product of several fractions where the factors in the numerator and denominator “match.”

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:
\(\frac{-54}{9} \cdot \frac{a^6}{a^4} \cdot \frac{b^3}{b^2}\)

  1. Now we can simplify the fraction multiplication and use the Quotient Property to divide.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:
\(\frac{-54}{9} \cdot \frac{a^6}{a^4} \cdot \frac{b^3}{b^2} = -6 \cdot a^2 \cdot b\)

So \(-54a^6b^3 \div 9a^4b^2 = -6a^2b\).

To divide a polynomial by a monomial, divide each term of the polynomial by the monomial.

  1. Find the quotient: \((18x^3y-36xy^2) \div (-3xy)\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:
Step 1
Rewrite as a fraction.
\(\frac{18x^3y-36xy^2}{-3xy}\)

Step 2
Divide each term by the divisor.
\(\frac{18x^3y}{-3xy}-\frac{36xy^2}{-3xy}\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(-6x^2+12y\)

  1. Find the quotient: \((-48a^8b^4-36a^6b^5) \div (-6a^3b^3)\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:
\( 8a^5b+6a^3b^2\)

  1. Find the quotient: \((-72g^4h^6-45g^7h^3) \div (9g^3h^3)\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:
\(-8gh^3-5g^4\)

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their interpretations of how to divide monomials. Emphasize the following points while considering this example: \(21x^5y^2 \div -3x^2y\).

  • Consider the coefficients and variables separately. To help ensure the division is done correctly, the expression can be written in an expanded form grouping common bases, \(\frac{21}{7} \cdot \frac{x^5}{x^3} \cdot \frac{y^2}{y}\).
  • Divide the coefficients. \(\frac{21}{7}=3\)
  • For the variables, divide using the Quotient Property for exponents.
    • \(\frac{x^5}{x^3}=x^2\)
    • \(\frac{y^2}{y}=y\)
  • Multiply the coefficients and variables as found in the previous steps.
    • \(3 \cdot x^2 \cdot y = 3x^2y\)

page.title: 6.3.2: Dividing Polynomials Using Long Division
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces students to using the process of long division to divide polynomials. In the same way that numbers are divided using long division, polynomials can also be divided. While the process is similar, students will learn to use placeholders, such as \(0x^2\), to stand in for a missing term of each degree in a polynomial dividend.

Launch

Display the traditional division problem \(960 \div 20\) to students. As a class, work through each individual step, displayed below. If more guidance is needed describing each step, see the Additional Resources section for the detailed description of a similar problem.

\[\begin{array}{l}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,48\\20\left){\vphantom{1{960}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{960}}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - 80} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,160\\\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - 160} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]

Explain that we will use this process to divide polynomials. Work together to solve the division expression, \((m^2+9m+20) \div (m+4)\), provided in the activity. Ask students to describe each step in the process as they have just done it in the long division problem above. Emphasize that the divisor, \(20\), was one quantity in the process above, so \((m + 4)\) will be one quantity in the process here. Help guide each step if any direction is needed.

Allow time for students to complete the remaining exercises individually.

Student Activity

Recall the process of dividing \(960 \div 20\) as a class using long division. Use this same method to divide the polynomials below.

  1. Find the quotient using long division.

    2. \((m^2+9m+20) \div (m+4)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \(m + 5\);

\[\begin{array}{l}m + 4\mathop{\left){\vphantom{1{{m^2} + 9m + 20}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{{m^2} + 9m + 20}}}}
\limits^{\displaystyle\,\,\, {m\,\, + \,\,5}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ({m^2} + 4m)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,5m + 20\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline {\, - (5m + 20)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]

  1. Find the quotient using long division.

    2. \((p^2+2p-8) \div (p^2-7p+10)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \(1+ \frac{9p-18}{p^2-7p+10}\)

  1. Find the quotient using long division.

    2. \((5x+5) \div (x+5)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \(5- \frac{20}{x+5}\)

Notice in the next problem, there is no \(x^3\) term in the dividend. Add \(0x^3\) as a placeholder when using long division.

  1. Find the quotient using long division.

    2. \((x^4-11x^2-7x-6) \div (x+3)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \(x^3-3x^2-2x-1-\frac{3}{x+3}\)

In this next problem, you will need to add two placeholders to divide.

  1. Find the quotient using long division.

    2. \((125x^3-8) \div (5x-2)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \(25x^2+10x+4\)


Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

Find the quotient using long division.

\((125y^5-80y^4-31y^3+37y^2+10y-24) \div (5y-4)\)

ANSWER: \(25y^4+4y^3-3y^2+5y+6\)

\[\begin{array}{l}5y - 4\mathop{\left){\vphantom{1{125{y^5} - 80{y^4} - 31{y^3} + 37{y^2} + 10y - 24}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{125{y^5} - 80{y^4} - 31{y^3} + 37{y^2} + 10y - 24}}}}
\limits^{\displaystyle\,\,\, {25{y^4} + \,\,\,4{y^3}\,\, - \,\,3{y^2}\,\, + \,\,5y\,\,\, + \,\,6\,}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (125{y^5} - 100{y^4})} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,20{y^4} - 31{y^3}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (20{y^4} - 16{y^3})} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, - \,15{y^3} + 37{y^2}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ( - \,15{y^3} + 12{y^2})} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,25{y^2} + 10y\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (25{y^2} - 20y)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,30y - 24\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (30y - 24)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]

Anticipated Misconceptions

As students complete the polynomial long division process, students may try to break apart a binomial divisor into individual monomials. Emphasize that the divisor will always be a single quantity in this process.

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share questions from the activity. Address any misconceptions about the process. Use the following key concepts to help reinforce the process:

  • Long division can be performed on polynomials using a very similar process to how it is done using number quantities.
  • When performing long division on polynomials, as in other long division, making sure all values are properly aligned is helpful to streamline the process and avoid errors.
  • When the dividend is missing terms of each degree from the highest degree down to a degree of zero, add in placeholders with a coefficient of \(0\).
  • When you find a remainder, it should be written as a fraction with the remainder in the numerator and the divisor in the denominator.
  • You can check your solution by multiplying it by the divisor. The product should be equal to the dividend in the original problem.

Video: Dividing Polynomials Using Long Division

Watch the following video to learn more about how to divide polynomials using long division.



6.3.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Find the quotient: \((3x^3-19x^2-9x-35) \div (x-7)\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(3x^2+40x+5\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the second term in your long division. Did you make a mistake with a sign? The answer is \(3x^2+2x+5\).

\(3x^2+2x+5\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x-7)(3x^2+2x+5)\). The product is \(3x^3-19x^2-9x-35\).

\(3x^2+2x-23\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the third term in your long division. Did you make a mistake with a sign? The answer is \(3x^2+2x+5\).

\(x^2+2x+5\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the first term in your long division. The answer is \(3x^2+2x+5\).

6.3.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Dividing Polynomials Using Long Division

To divide a polynomial by a binomial, we follow a procedure very similar to long division of numbers. So let’s look carefully at the steps we take when we divide a \(3\)-digit number, \(875\), by a \(2\)-digit number, \(25\).

Step 1
Starting from the leftmost digit in the dividend and moving right one digit at a time, find the smallest value possible that is larger than the divisor. Divide this value, \(87\), by the divisor, \(25\). Write the whole-number result with no remainder in the space for the quotient.

Step 2
Multiply this digit in the quotient by the divisor, \(3 \cdot 25\). Write the result below the corresponding digits in the dividend.

Step 3
Subtract the two values.

Step 4
Bring down the next digit in the dividend.

Step 5
Repeat the division by dividing the new value, \(125\), by the divisor. Write the result, \(5\), over the corresponding digit in the quotient.

Step 6
Multiply this digit in the quotient by the divisor, \(5 \cdot 25\). Write the result at the bottom below the previous number.

Step 7
Subtract the two values. Since there are no more digits to bring down, this value is the remainder. The quotient is on top.

We check division by multiplying the quotient by the divisor.

If we did the division correctly, the product should equal the dividend.

  • \(35 \cdot 25\)
  • \(875{\style{color:red}✓}\)

Now we will divide a trinomial by a binomial. As you read through the example, notice how similar the steps are to the numerical example above.

EXAMPLE 1

Find the quotient: \((x^2+9x+20) \div (x+5)\).

Step 1:
Write it as a long division problem. Be sure the dividend is in standard form.

Step 2
Divide \(x^2\) by \(x\). It may help to ask yourself, “What do I need to multiply \(x\) by to get \(x^2\)?”

Step 3
Put the answer, \(x\), in the quotient over the \(x\) term. Multiply \(x\) times \(x + 5\). Line up the like terms under the dividend.

Step 4
Subtract \(x^2 + 5x\) from \(x^2 + 9x\). You may find it easier to change the signs and then add. Then bring down the last term, \(20\).

Step 5
Divide \(4x\) by \(x\). It may help to ask yourself, “What do I need to multiply \(x\) by to get \(4x\)?” Put the answer, \(4\), in the quotient over the constant term.

Step 6
Multiply \(4\) times \(x+5\).

Step 7
Subtract \(4x+20\) from \(4x+20\).

Step 8
Check: Multiply the quotient by the divisor. You should get the dividend.
\((x+4)(x+5)\)
\(x^2+9x+20{\style{color:red}✓}\)

When we divided \(875\) by \(25\), we had no remainder. But sometimes division of numbers does leave a remainder. The same is true when we divide polynomials. In the next example, we’ll have division that leaves a remainder. We write the remainder as a fraction with the divisor as the denominator.

Look back at the dividend in the previous example. The terms were written in descending order of degrees, and there were no missing degrees. The dividend in the next example will be \(x^4-x^2+5^x-6\). It is missing an \(x^3\) term. We will add in \(0x^3\) as a placeholder.

EXAMPLE 2

Find the quotient: \((x^4-x^2+5x-6) \div (x+2)\).

Notice that there is no \(x^3\) term in the dividend. We will add \(0x^3\) as a placeholder.

Step 1
Write it as a long division problem. Be sure the dividend is in standard form with placeholders for missing terms.

Step 2
Divide \(x^4\) by \(x\).
Put the answer, \(x^3\), in the quotient over the \(x^3\) term. Multiply \(x^3\) times \(x+2\). Line up the like terms. Subtract and then bring down the next term.

Step 3
Divide \(-2x^3\) by \(x\).
Put the answer, \(-2x^2\), in the quotient over the \(x^2\) term. Multiply \(-2x^2\) times \(x+1\). Line up the like terms. Subtract and bring down the next term.

Step 4
Divide \(3x^2\) by \(x\).
Put the answer, \(3x\), in the quotient over the \(x\) term. Multiply \(3x\) times \(x+1\). Line up the like terms. Subtract and bring down the next term.

Step 5
Divide \(-x\) by \(x\). Put the answer, \(-1\), in the quotient over the constant term. Multiply \(-1\) times \(x+1\). Line up the like terms. Change the signs and then add. Write the remainder as a fraction with the divisor as the denominator.

Step 6
To check, multiply \((x+2)(x^3−2x^2+3x−1−\frac{4}{x+2})\). The result should be \(x^4−x^2+5x−6\).

In the next example, we will divide by \(2a+3\). As we divide, we will have to consider the coefficients as well as the variables.

EXAMPLE 3

Find the quotient: \((8a^3+27) \div (2a+3)\).

This time, we will show the division all in one step. We need to add two placeholders to divide.

To check, multiply \((2a+3)(4a^2-6a+9)\).

The result should be \(8a^3+27\).

Try It: Dividing Polynomials Using Long Division

Find the quotients.

  1. \((y^2+10y+21) \div (y+3)\)
  1. \((x^4-7x^2+7x+6) \div (x+3) \)
  1. \((x^3-64) \div (x-4) \)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to divide these polynomials using long division:

  1. \( y + 7\);

\[\begin{array}{l}y + 3\mathop{\left){\vphantom{1{{y^2} + 10y + 21}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{{y^2} + 10y + 21}}}}
\limits^{\displaystyle\,\,\, {y\,\, + \,\,7}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ({y^2} + 7y)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,3y + 21\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (3y + 21)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]

  1. \(x^3-3x^2+2x+1+\frac{3}{x+3}\);

\[\begin{array}{l}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,{x^3} - 3{x^2} + 2x + 1\\x + 3\sqrt {{x^4} + 0{x^3} - 7{x^2} + 7x + 6} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ({x^4} + 3{x^3})} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, - 3{x^3} - 7{x^2}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ( - 3{x^3} - 9{x^2})} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,2{x^2} + 7x\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (2{x^2} + 6x)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,x + 6\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (x + 3)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,3\end{array}\]

  1. \( x^2+4x+16\);

\[\begin{array}{l}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,{x^2} + 4x + 16\\x - 4\left){\vphantom{1{{x^3} + 0{x^2} + 0x - 64}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{{x^3} + 0{x^2} + 0x - 64}}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ({x^3} - 4{x^2})} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,4{x^2} + 0x\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (4{x^2} - 16x)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,16x - 64\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - (16x - 64)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]

page.title: 6.3.3: Dividing Polynomials Using Synthetic Division
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces a new method for dividing polynomials. Synthetic division is a process to divide polynomials that streamlines the steps as compared to long division. It works for dividing by any binomial of the form \(x - c\), where \(c\) is a constant. The dividend can be a polynomial with terms of higher degrees.

This lesson represents an extension from the TEKS listed and can be used as an enrichment to enhance the students’ understanding of dividing polynomials.

Launch

Ask students to divide the first example, \((x^2-13x+42) \div (x-6)\), using long division. Use the reveal to allow them to check their answer when completed.

Tell students there is a more efficient way to divide a polynomial by a binomial. Emphasize that this method only applies to division of a polynomial by a binomial. Also stress that the divisor must be written in the format \(x - c\), where \(c\) is a constant.

Click the reveal to show the synthetic division process on the same division problem. Guide students through each step, stopping for any clarification as needed.

Arrange the students into pairs. Allow students the remaining time to work through division problems 1–4 in pairs.

Student Activity

In this activity, we’re going to use synthetic division to divide a polynomial by a binomial.

First, divide \((x^2-13x+42) \div (x-6)\) using long division.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution:

\[\begin{array}{l}x - 6\mathop{\left){\vphantom{1{{x^2} - 13x + 42}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{{x^2} - 13x + 42}}}}
\limits^{\displaystyle\,\,\, {x\,\, - 7}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ({x^2} - 6x)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, - 7x + 42\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ( - 7x + 42)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]

You are now going to solve the same division problem using synthetic division.

Select the Solution button to show the method.

Solution

\((x^2-13x+42) \div (x-6)\)

Step 1
Write the dividend with decreasing powers of \(x\). Make sure there is no degree missing from the highest degree down to a degree of \(0\).
\(x^2-13x+42\)

Step 2
Write the coefficients of the terms as the first row of the synthetic division.

Step 3
Write the divisor as \(x - c\) and place \(c\) in the synthetic division in the divisor box.

Step 4
Bring down the first coefficient to the third row.

Step 5
Multiply that coefficient by the divisor and place the result in the second row under the second coefficient.

Step 6
Add the second column, putting the result in the third row.

Step 7
Multiply that result by the divisor and place the result in the second row under the third coefficient.

Step 8
Add the final column, putting the result in the third row.

Step 9
The division is complete. The numbers in the third row give us the result. The \(1\) \( −7\) in the third row are the coefficients of the quotient. The quotient is \(x - 7\). The \(0\) in the box in the third row is the remainder.


Work with a partner to find each quotient. Discuss any differences you have in determining the correct solution.

  1. \( (4x^3+5x^2-5x+3) \div (x+2)\)

ANSWER: \(4x^2-3x+1\); remainder of 1

  1. \((2x^3-11x^2+16x-12) \div (x -4)\)

ANSWER: \(2x^2-3x+4\); remainder of 4

  1. \( (x^4-9x^2+2x+6) \div (x + 3)\)

ANSWER: \(x^3-3x^2+2\); remainder of 0

  1. \((3x^4-11x^3+2x^2+10x+6) \div (x - 3)\)

ANSWER: \(3x^3-2x^2-4x-2\); remainder of 0

Anticipated Misconceptions

It is important for students to recognize that synthetic division only works when the divisor is of the form \(x - c\). If the divisor is already in the form \(x - c\), such as \(x - 3\), then \(3\) will go into the box in the top-left corner of the synthetic division. If the divisor is \(x + 5\), then it must be converted into the form \(x - c\) by adding the appropriate signs to maintain equivalency. Since \(x + 5 = x - (-5)\), \(-5\) would go into the box in the top-left corner.

Activity Synthesis

Remember these key points to help students summarize the lesson:

  • Synthetic division is only useful when the divisor is a binomial of the form \(x - c\), where \(c\) is a constant.
  • The dividend can be a polynomial with terms of higher degrees. When completing synthetic division, arrange the terms of the dividend in descending order according to degree. Add placeholders with a \(0\) coefficient for any terms that are missing, such as \(0x^3\).
  • The final number in the third row is the remainder. The remainder is expressed as a fraction with the value from the synthetic division as the numerator and the divisor as the denominator.

6.3.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Use synthetic division to find the quotient and remainder when \(x^4+x^2+6x-10\) is divided by \(x + 2\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x^3-x^2+8x\); remainder of \(26\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember to use \(0x^3\) as a placeholder in the dividend. The answer is \(x^3-2x^2+5x-4\); remainder of \(-2\).

\(x^3-2x^2+5x-4\); remainder of \(0\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your calculation on the remainder. The answer is \(x^3-2x^2+5x-4\); remainder of \(-2\).

\(x^3-2x^2+5x-4\); remainder of \(2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your calculation on the remainder. The answer is \(x^3-2x^2+5x-4\); remainder of \(-2\).

\(x^3-2x^2+5x-4\); remainder of \(-2\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x^3-2x^2+5x-4)(x+2)\) and add \(-2\). Since this equals \(x^4+x^2+6x-10\), it is correct.

6.3.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Dividing Polynomials Using Synthetic Division

Mathematicians like to find patterns to make their work easier. Since long division can be tedious, let’s look back at the long division we did in a previous example and look for some patterns. We will use this as a basis for what is called synthetic division. The same problem in the synthetic division format is shown next.

Synthetic division basically just removes unnecessary repeated variables and numbers. Here, all the \(x\) and \(x^2\) are removed as well as the \(-x^2\) and \(-4x\) because they are opposite the term above.

The first row of the synthetic division is the coefficients of the dividend. The \(-5\) is the opposite of the \(5\) in the divisor.

The second row of the synthetic division is the numbers shown in red in the division problem.

The third row of the synthetic division is the numbers shown in blue in the division problem.

Notice the quotient and remainder are shown in the third row.

Synthetic division only works when the divisor is of the form \(x-c\).

The following example will explain the process.

EXAMPLE 1

Use synthetic division to find the quotient and remainder when \(2x^3+3x^2+x+8\) is divided by \(x + 2\).

Step 1
Write the dividend with decreasing powers of \(x\).
\(2x^3+3x^2+x+8\)

Step 2
Write the coefficients of the terms as the first row of the synthetic division.

Step 3
Write the divisor as \(x-c\) and place \(c\) in the synthetic division in the divisor box.

Step 4
Bring down the first coefficient to the third row.

Step 5
Multiply that coefficient by the divisor and place the result in the second row under the second coefficient.

Step 6
Add the second column, putting the result in the third row.

Step 7
Multiply that result by the divisor and place the result in the second row under the third coefficient.

Step 8
Add the third column, putting the result in the third row.

Step 9
Multiply that result by the divisor and place the result in the third row under the third coefficient.

Step 10
Add the final column, putting the result in the third row.

Step 11
The quotient is \(2x^2-1x+3\), and the remainder is \(2\).


The division is complete. The numbers in the third row give us the result. The \(2\) \(-1\) \(3\) are the coefficients of the quotient. The quotient is \(2x^2-1x+3\). The \(2\) in the box in the third row is the remainder.

Check your work:

(quotient)(divisor) + remainder = dividend ( 2 x 2 − 1 x + 3 ) ( x + 2 ) + 2 = ? 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 2 x 3 − x 2 + 3 x + 4 x 2 − 2 x + 6 + 2 = ? 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 = 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 ✓ (quotient)(divisor) + remainder = dividend ( 2 x 2 − 1 x + 3 ) ( x + 2 ) + 2 = ? 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 2 x 3 − x 2 + 3 x + 4 x 2 − 2 x + 6 + 2 = ? 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 = 2 x 3 + 3 x 2 + x + 8 ✓

EXAMPLE 2

Use synthetic division to find the quotient and remainder when \(x^4-16x^2+3x+12\) is divided by \(x + 4\).

The polynomial \(x^4-16x^2+3x+12\) has its terms in order with descending degree, but we notice there is no \(x^3\) term. We will add a \(0\) as a placeholder for the \(x^3\) term. In \(x - c\) form, the divisor is \(x-(-4)\).

We divided a 4th degree polynomial by a 1st degree polynomial, so the quotient will be a 3rd degree polynomial. Reading from the third row, the quotient has the coefficients \(1\) \(-4\) \(0\) \(3\), which is \(x^3-4x^2+3\). The remainder is \(0\).

Try It: Dividing Polynomials Using Synthetic Division

  1. Use synthetic division to find the quotient and remainder when \(3x^3+10x^2+6x-2\) is divided by \(x + 2\).
  1. Use synthetic division to find the quotient and remainder when \(x^4-16x^2+5x+20\) is divided by \(x + 4\).

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find these quotients using synthetic division:

  1. \( 3x^2+4x-2\); remainder of \(2\)

\(\begin{array}{l}\left. {\underline {\,
{ - 2} \,}}\! \right| \,\,\,\,\,3\,\,\,\,\,\,10\,\,\,\,\,\,6\,\,\,\,\, - 2\\\underline {\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, - 6\,\,\,\, - 8\,\,\,\,\,\,\,4\,\,} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,3\,\,\,\,\,\,4\,\,\,\,\, - 2\,\,\,\,\,\,\left| \!{\overline {\,
2 \,}} \right. \end{array}\)

  1. \(x^3-4x^2+5\); remainder of \(0\)

\(\begin{array}{l}\left. {\underline {\,
{ - 4} \,}}\! \right| \,\,\,\,\,1\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\,\,\,\,\,\, - 16\,\,\,\,\,\,\,5\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,20\\\underline {\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, - 4\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,16\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\,\,\,\, - 20\,} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,1\,\,\,\,\, - 4\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,5\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\left| \!{\overline {\,
0 \,}} \right. \end{array}\)

page.title: 6.3.4: Dividing Polynomial Functions and the Remainder Theorem
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces the division of polynomial functions. Polynomial functions can be divided just as polynomials have been in the previous activities. Division involving polynomial functions can be represented in the format \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\) or \(\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\).

This lesson represents an extension from the TEK listed and can be used as an enrichment to enhance the students’ understanding of dividing polynomials.

Launch

Tell students that now that they have practiced dividing polynomials, polynomial functions can be divided in the same way.

Allow 7–10 minutes for students to complete questions 1–3 in the activity. If there is any confusion, solve the first question as a class.

Introduce the Remainder Theorem:

  • If a polynomial function \(f(x)\) is divided by \(x-c\), then the remainder is \(f(c)\).

Stress to students that the divisor must be in the form \(x-c\), as was the case for synthetic division. By simply finding the value, \(f(c)\), the remainder can be determined. Allow students 5–7 minutes to solve questions 4–5.

Student Activity

Divide the polynomial functions. Find the quotient value.

  1. \(f(x)=x^2-5x-24\)
    \(g(x)=x+3\)

    \((\frac{f}{g})(x) =\) ___________

    \((\frac{f}{g})(-3) =\) ___________

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x-8\); \((\frac{f}{g})(-3)=-11\)

  1. \(f(x)=x^2-15x+54\)
    \(g(x)=x-9\)

    \((\frac{f}{g})(x) =\) ___________

    \((\frac{f}{g})(-5) =\) ___________

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x-6\); \((\frac{f}{g})(-5)=-11\)

  1. \(f(x)=x^2+2x-3\)
    \(g(x)=x+3\)

    \((\frac{f}{g})(x) =\) ___________

    \((\frac{f}{g})(3) =\) ___________

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER: \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x-1\); \((\frac{f}{g})(3)=2\)

The Remainder Theorem states that if a polynomial function \(f(x)\) is divided by \(x-c\), then the remainder is \(f(c)\). This means we can always check the remainder by finding \(f(c)\) when the divisor is written in the form \(x-c\).

  1. Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder when \(f(x)=x^3-7x+12\) is divided by \(x + 3\).

ANSWER: 6

  1. Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder when \(f(x)=2x^3-6x-24\) is divided by \(x - 3\).

ANSWER: 12

Activity Synthesis

Students should be familiar with polynomial division by this activity. Emphasize that the process of dividing polynomial functions is the same as they learned in previous activities. Students should remember that for functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\), where \(g(x) \neq 0\), \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\).

Ask the class to explain the Remainder Theorem. Emphasize the following key points:

  • The Remainder Theorem states if a polynomial function \(f(x)\) is divided by \(x - c\), then the remainder is \(f(c)\).
  • When finding the value of \(c\), the divisor must be written in the form \(x - c\). This means that for a divisor of \(x + 6\), the value of \(c\) would be \(-6\).

6.3.4: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

For functions \(f(x)=x^3+2x^2-19x+12\) and \(g(x)=x-3\):

Find \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\) and \((\frac{f}{g})(0)\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x^2+5x-4\)

\((\frac{f}{g})(0)=-4\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x^2+5x-4)(x-3)\) to get \(x^3+2x^2-19x+12\). The answer is correct.

\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=xa^2+5x-4\)

\((\frac{f}{g})(0)=12\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the value you found for \((\frac{f}{g})(0)\). You found \(f(0)\). The answer is \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x^2+5x-4\) and \((\frac{f}{g})(0)=-4\).

\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x^2+5x+4\)

\((\frac{f}{g})(0)=4\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the signs in your division. The answer is \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x^2+5x-4\) and \((\frac{f}{g})(0)=-4\).

\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x^2-5x+4\)

\((\frac{f}{g})(0)=-4\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the signs in your division. The answer is \((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x^2+5x-4\) and \((\frac{f}{g})(0)=-4\).

6.3.4: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Dividing Polynomial Functions

Just as polynomials can be divided, polynomial functions can also be divided.


DIVISION OF POLYNOMIAL FUNCTIONS

For functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\), where \(g(x) \neq 0\),

\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\)


EXAMPLE 1

For functions \(f(x)=x^2-5x-14\) and \(g(x)=x+2\):

  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\).

Step 1
\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\)
Substitute for \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\).
\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=\frac{f(x)=x^2-5x-14}{x+2}\)

Step 2
Divide the polynomials using long division.
\[\begin{array}{l}\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,x - 7\\x + 2\left){\vphantom{1{{x^2} - 5x - 14}}}\right.
\!\!\!\!\overline{\,\,\,\vphantom 1{{{x^2} - 5x - 14}}}\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ({x^2} + 2x)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, - 7x - 14\\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\underline { - ( - 7x - 14)} \\\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,0\end{array}\]
\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x-7\)


  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(-4)\).

Step 1
In part (1), we found \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\).
\((\frac{f}{g})(x)=x−7\)

Step 2
To find \((\frac{f}{g})(-4)\), substitute \(x=-4\).
\((\frac{f}{g})(-4)=-4-7\)
\((\frac{f}{g})(-4)=-11\)


Try It: Dividing Polynomial Functions

For functions \(f(x)=x^2-5x-36\) and \(g(x)=x+4\):

  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\).
  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(-5)\).

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve these polynomial function division problems:

  1. \((\frac{f}{g})(x) = \frac{x^2-5x-36}{x+4}=x-9\)
  1. \((\frac{f}{g})(-5)=x-9=(-5)-9=-14\)

Using the Remainder Theorem

Let’s look at some division problems and their remainders. They are summarized in the chart below. If we take the dividend from each division problem and use it to define a function, we get the functions shown in the chart. When the divisor is written as \(x - c\), the value of the function at \(c\), \(f(c)\), is the same as the remainder from the division problem.

Dividend

Divisor \(x - c\)

Remainder

Function

\(f(c)\)

\(x^4-7x^2+7x+6\)

\(x - (-3)\)

\(3\)

\(f(x)=x^4-7x^2+7x+6\)

\(f(-3)=-3\)

\(y^2+10y+21\)

\(x - (-3)\)

\(0\)

\(f(x)=3x^3-2x^2-10x+8\)

\(f(-3)=0\)

\(x^4-16x^2+3x+15\)

\(x - (-4)\)

\(3\)

\(f(x)=x^4-16x^2+3x+15\)

\(f(-4)=3\)

To see this more generally, we realize we can check a division problem by multiplying the quotient times the divisor and adding the remainder. In function notation, we could say: To get the dividend \(f(x)\), we multiply the quotient, \(q(x)\), times the divisor, \(x-c\), and add the remainder, \(r\).

\(f(x)=q(x)(x-c)+r\)

If we evaluate this at \(c\), we get:

\(f({\style{color:red}c})=q({\style{color:red}c})({\style{color:red}c}-c)+r\)
\(f(c)=q(c)(0)+r\)
\(f(c)=r\)

This leads us to the Remainder Theorem.


REMAINDER THEOREM

If the polynomial function \(f(x)\) is divided by \(x-c\), then the remainder is \(f(c)\).


EXAMPLE 2

Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder when \(f(x)=x^3+3x+19\) is divided by \(x + 2\).

To use the Remainder Theorem, we must use the divisor in the \(x-c\) form. We can write the divisor \(x+2\) as \(x-(-2)\). So, our \(c\) is \(-2\).

To find the remainder, we evaluate \(f(c)\), which is \(f(-2)\).

\(f(x)=x^3+3x+19\)

Step 1
To evaluate \(f(-2)\), substitute \(x=-2\).
\(f({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})=({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})^3+3({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})+19\)

Step 2
Simplify.
\(f(-2)=(-8)-6+19\)
\(f(-2)=5\)
The remainder is 5 when \(f(x)=x^3+3x+19\) is divided by \(x+2\).

Step 3
Check: Use synthetic division to check.

The remainder is 5.

Try It: Using the Remainder Theorem

Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder when \(f(x)=x^3+4x+15\) is divided by \(x + 2\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve a problem using the Remainder Theorem:

\(f(x)=x^3+4x+15\)
\(f(2)=(-2)^3+4(-2)+15\)
\(f(2)=-8-8+15= -1\)

The remainder is \(-1\).

page.title: 6.3.5: Using the Factor Theorem
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

In all the division problems we completed that had a remainder of zero, we say that the divisor was a factor of the dividend.

Whenever a divisor, \(x-c\), divides a polynomial function, \(f(x)\), and results in a remainder of zero, we say \(x-c\) is a factor of \(f(x)\).

This leads us to the Factor Theorem.


FACTOR THEOREM

For any polynomial function \(f(x)\),

  • if \(x-c\) is a factor of \(f(x)\), then \(f(c)=0\).
  • if \(f(c)=0\), then \(x-c\) is a factor of \(f(x)\).

Use the Factor Theorem to determine whether the binomial is a factor of the given polynomial function.

Binomial \((x – c)\)

Polynomial function

Is it a factor?

\(x - 5\)

\(f(x)=x^3-125\)

 a. ___

\(x - 6\)

\(f(x)=x^3-216\)

 b. ___

\(x + 3\)

\(f(x)=x^3+8x^2+21x+18\)

 c. ___

\(x + 4\)

\(f(x)=x^3+x^2-14x+8\)

 d. ___

  1. Is \((x - 5)\) a factor of \(f(x)=x^3-125\)?

ANSWER: Yes

  1. Is \((x - 6)\) a factor of \(f(x)=x^3-216\)?

ANSWER: Yes

  1. Is \((x + 3)\) a factor of \(f(x)=x^3+8x^2+21x+18\)?

ANSWER: Yes

  1. Is \((x + 4)\) a factor of \(f(x)=x^3+x^2-14x+8\)?

ANSWER: No

page.title: 6.3.6: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–2, divide.

  1. \(\frac{45x^5y^9}{-60x^8y^6}\)
    • \(-\frac{3x^3}{4y^3}\)
    • \(-\frac{4y^3}{3x^3}\)
    • \(-\frac{3y^3}{4x^3}\)
    • \(-\frac{3}{4}x^3y^3\)

ANSWER:\(-\frac{3y^3}{4x^3}\)

  1. \((48y^4-24y^3) \div (-8y^2)\)
    • \(-6y^2+3y\)
    • \(-3y^2\)
    • \(-6y+3y^2\)
    • \(-6y^3+3y\)

ANSWER:\(-6y^2+3y\)

For questions 3–4, divide using long division.

  1. \((m^3+1000) \div (m+10)\)
    • \(m^2+10m\)
    • \( m^2-100\)
    • \(m^2+10m-100\)
    • \(m^2-10m+100\)

ANSWER:\(m^2-10m+100\)

  1. \((125y^3-64) \div (5y+4)\)
    • \(25y^2-20y+16- \frac{128}{5y+4}\)
    • \(25y^2-20y+16- \frac{64}{5y+4}\)
    • \(25y^2+20y+16\)
    • \(25y^2-20y+16\)

ANSWER: \(25y^2-20y+16- \frac{128}{5y+4}\)

For questions 5–6, divide using synthetic division.

  1. \((b^3-3b^2-4b+12) \div (b+2)\)
    • \(b^2+5b\); remainder \(6\)
    • \( b^2-5b+6\); remainder \(0\)
    • \(b^2-5b\); remainder \(6\)
    • \(b^2+5b-6\); remainder \(0\)

ANSWER: \( b^2-5b+6\); remainder \(0\)

  1. \((3x^4-11x^3+2x^2+10x+6) \div (x-3)\)
    • \(3x^3+2x^2+4x+2\); remainder \(0\)
    • \(3x^3-20x^2-62x-180\); remainder \(0\)
    • \(3x^3-2x^2-4x-2\); remainder \(0\)
    • \(3x^3-2x^2-4x\); remainder \(–2\)

ANSWER:\(3x^3-2x^2-4x-2\); remainder \(0\)

For questions 7–8, use the following polynomial functions.

  • \(f(x)=x^2-13x+36\)
  • \(g(x)=x-4\)
  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\).
    • \(x+9\)
    • \(x-12\)
    • \(x-3\)
    • \(x-9\)

ANSWER: \(x-9\)

  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(-1)\).
    • \(-8\)
    • \( -10\)
    • \( -4\)
    • \( 8\)

ANSWER:\(-10\)

  1. Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder.

\(f(x)=x^2-4x-9\) is divided by \(x + 2\)

  • \(3\)
  • \(21\)
  • \(-13\)
  • \(-9\)

ANSWER:\(3\)

  1. Use the Factor Theorem to determine if \(x-c\) is a factor of the polynomial function.
    Determine whether \(x - 3\) is a factor of \(x^3-7x^2+11x+3\).
    • Yes
    • No

ANSWER: Yes

page.title: 6.3.7: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To help students summarize the skills they learned dividing polynomials, emphasize the following points:

  • Divide monomials by monomials by dividing the coefficients and then dividing the variables using the Quotient Property for exponents.
  • Divide a polynomial by a monomial by distributing the division of the monomial to each term in the polynomial dividend.
  • The solution to your division problem can alway be checked by multiplying the solution by the divisor to see if the product matches the original dividend.
  • To divide a polynomial by another polynomial, use long division as you have previously learned using numbers.
  • An efficient method to divide a polynomial by a binomial is synthetic division.
    • The divisor must be in the form \(x - c\), where \(c\) is a constant.
    • Use a placeholder with a \(0\) coefficient, such as \(0x^2\), for any term that is missing in the dividend from the term with the highest degree down to a degree of \(0\).
    • The bottom-right number in the third row of the synthetic division is the remainder.
  • Polynomial functions can be divided using the same methods as with other polynomials.
  • Use the Remainder Theorem to easily find the value of a remainder in any polynomial division problem.
  • Use the Factor Theorem to determine if a divisor is a factor of a larger polynomial.
